maml:description.maml:para: Adds an infrastructure server to an IPAM database.

The Add-IpamServerInventory cmdlet adds a new infrastructure server to the IP Address Management (IPAM) server inventory. Use the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the server to add to the server inventory.
Specifies the FQDN of the infrastructure server to add to the server inventory.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies custom metadata for the server.
Specifies a description for the server.

Specifies the manageability status of a server. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Unspecified -- Managed -- Unmanaged
IPAM gathers data from the server if this parameter is set to Managed.
Specifies the owner of the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Specifies an array of server roles that are present on the server. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- DC -- DHCP -- DNS -- NPS
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies custom metadata for the server.
Specifies a description for the server.

Specifies the manageability status of a server. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Unspecified -- Managed -- Unmanaged
IPAM gathers data from the server if this parameter is set to Managed.
Specifies the FQDN of the infrastructure server to add to the server inventory.
Specifies the owner of the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

-- DC -- DHCP -- DNS -- NPS

If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Represents an infrastructure server in IPAM system.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Add a server to the IPAM server inventory

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a server named Dhcp01.Contoso.com to the IPAM server inventory.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the properties of managed servers in the IPAM server inventory.

The Get-IpamServerInventory cmdlet gets the list of managed servers in the IP Address Management (IPAM) server inventory. Managed servers include the servers that perform domain controller (DC), Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP), Domain Name Service (DNS), or Network Policy Server (NPS) roles. You can filter the list of servers based on address family, the type of server role, or a list of fully qualified domain names (FQDNs).
Specifies an array of address families to which the infrastructure server belongs. The acceptable values for this parameter are: IPv4 or IPv6.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies an array of server roles on which to filter the results.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies fully qualified domain names of the servers for which to retrieve data.
Specifies an array of address families to which the infrastructure server belongs. The acceptable values for this parameter are: IPv4 or IPv6.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies fully qualified domain names of the servers for which to retrieve data.
Specifies an array of server roles on which to filter the results.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Represents a managed infrastructure server in IPAM system.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get all IPv4 servers in the IPAM server inventory
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-IpamServerInventory -AddressFamily IPv4 | Format-List Name, ServerType Name : dhcp1.contoso.com
ServerType : DHCP Name : DC1.contoso.com
ServerType : DC

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all IPv4 servers in the IPAM server inventory.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get all IPv4 DHSP servers in the IPAM server inventory
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\>Get-IpamServerInventory -AddressFamily IPv4 -ServerType DHCP| Format-List Name, ServerType Name : dhcp1.contoso.com
ServerType : DHCP

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all IPv4 DHCP servers in the IPAM server inventory.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a server from an IPAM server inventory.

The Remove-IpamServerInventory cmdlet removes an infrastructure server from an IP Address Management (IPAM) server inventory. After you remove the server, IPAM no longer manages the server and IPAM deletes the corresponding server data from the IPAM database. This cmdlet does not modify the configuration of the infrastructure server.
Specifies an array of servers to remove from an IPAM server inventory. Specify a server name or its fully qualified domain name (FQDN).

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Remove a server from the IPAM inventory
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-IpamServerInventory -Name "Dhcp01" Confirm Deleting server Dhcp01.contoso.com from IPAM server inventory. Do you want to continue?[Y]Yes [N] No [S] Suspend [?] Help (default is “Y”):

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the server named Dhcp01 from the IPAM server inventory.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies the properties of an infrastructure server in the IPAM server inventory.

The Set-IpamServerInventory cmdlet modifies the properties of an infrastructure server in an IP Address Management (IPAM) server inventory. Use the server name or fully qualified domain name (FQDN) to identify the server. If you only specify the server name, IPAM tries to resolve the server name.
Specifies the FQDN of the infrastructure server to modify.
Specifies the new name or FQDN of an infrastructure server. IPAM tries to resolve the name to an IP address and reports an error if it cannot resolve the name.
Specifies custom configuration to add to the server inventory.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies a description for the server.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.

Specifies the manageability status of a server. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Unspecified -- Managed -- Unmanaged
If you specify a value of Managed for this parameter, IPAM gathers data from the server.
Specifies the owner of the DHCP server.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the metadata fields to modify. List the metadata as a series of custom field names, separated by semicolons (;).

Specifies an array of server roles that are present on the server. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- DHCP -- DC -- DNS -- NPS

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies custom configuration to add to the server inventory.

To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

-- DHCP -- DC -- DNS -- NPS

If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Represents an infrastructure server in IPAM system.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Modify the properties of a server

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command modifies the properties of an infrastructure server named Dhcp01, and makes it manageable by IPAM.
